positive.review:
This game is unabashedly tabletop, clearly made by developers who love everything about pen & paper Pathfinder and old CRPGs. I've never played an RPG [i]this[/i] ambitious with its character building, or choices in dialogue and plot progression, but any buyer should be warned, this level of ambitiousness also means it's very possible this game is not for you. There's a particular type of player this game is made for, and the game doesn't bother appealing to anyone who doesn't fit in that group—if you're not a fan of walls of text coming at you from every box, just skip this.

WOTR ruined my ability to look back on other RPGs regarding character choice, it blows almost all of them out of the water, and without even showing you everything it has to offer. A criticism I can levy against the game is that this makes it all the more apparent when the developers do make a mistake and forget about something (typically in companion quests), but if something like this stands out like a massive issue in a particular quest rather than a commonly accepted fact of the game, then you know WOTR did it right. If you're a player like me, who enjoys "pushing the envelope" on what society considers "morally acceptable" in these games, and often gets assigned a red alignment card, WOTR has you covered in just about every way you can think of. Are you John Paladin the Bethesda Good Guy? Are you a brutal tyrant, lavishly treating yourself despite having no humanity to spare? Are you a walking embodiment of freedom and chaos, in fact, what does freedom and chaos even look like to you? Do you enjoy the dilemma of what responsibility regarding power actually means, when you're afforded power over time itself? All of these are afforded to you, down to the developers even catering to the type of player who just wants to kill everyone, and creating an interesting scenario around that rather than letting the game just fall apart because all of the characters are dead. That's not even close to the options afforded to you in the smaller scale quests, or just regular dialogue. The game also offers a good set of companions, though they take a backseat to you in the story. If you're expecting character-driven soap opera dialogue from them, you're not going to get it. This game is about you, not them.

The part of this game that will dissuade you most easily will be the actual gameplay part of it. For those who are unaware, the [i]Pathfinder[/i] system could more or less be described as "D&D 3.5 for Powergamers," and this game absolutely expects you to understand its systems going in, to the point of disabling the ability to respec on higher difficulties—which you might notice are actually the game's NORMAL difficulties, and the game's "Normal" mode is in fact easy mode. Combat itself is designed around quick encounters playing against resource drain much like a common random encounter in a tabletop game, and because of this, [b]this game should be played on RTWP, NOT turn-based.[/b] Turn-based exists for you to slow down combat in tense moments, but it should absolutely not be the primary way you play. Encounters take too long and there are too many of them. Additionally, if you don't plan on min-maxing, you should stay on the lower difficulties lest you face a miss-a-thon, and you'll likely have plenty of those early game regardless if you don't know what you're doing or decided to play a spellcaster.

As a side note, whoever designed encounters in this game should be burned at the stake. Despite being committed to offering you a tabletop experience, Owlcat is quite familiar with the Quicksave function, and when they discovered they could make a bunch of brutal, sudden encounters and get away with it because players could just reload their save, ideas began to come about in their head. Come the game's release, I have no doubt they were laughing, so hard they couldn't breathe. For a game as big as WOTR, it's to be expected there are many points without polish, and it suffers from the classic CRPG issue of running out of budget and having a lame final chapter, but there are many points in the game which are less "not very thought out" or "not very interesting" and instead that battle designer deciding he wanted to remind you who was the top bunk. This type of behavior would have players pouring cold soda down your shirt in an actual tabletop campaign, and as such, all players are encouraged to shun the battle designer of this game and speak of him only in whispers, lest he decide to drop more 900 AC instant kill enemies who resist all status effects and can only be killed by permanent attribute damage.

WOTR very quickly became one of my favorite games. I've replayed it multiple times, and consistently been impressed at how well made it is, and what the developers thought of as I played through it. Even as I played it, I kept wondering what my next playthrough would look like. I love the Lich, and I love the Swarm. Maybe a Hellknight Aeon playthrough next time...
The game is fun and has a great deal of replayability as there are different classes and mythic paths.

If you, like me, care mostly about how the RPG is written then this is the BEST RPG (and the best game overall) you can play... Yes, better than BG3, DOS2, Witcher 1/2/3, Cyberpunk, DA Origins, Mass Effect trilogy, ...

I have played all of those and I proudly say Pathfinder WOTR is MY Favorite game of all time.

Honestly, Wrath of the Righteous (WotR) may have its issues, but the writing and gameplay really are spectacular. The story is massive in scale and touches on a variety of important history in the setting (i.e. Pathfinder tabletop / the world of Golarion).

The build options for your character are MASSIVE; I've spent dozens of hours just respeccing and trying out new builds for the heck of it (especially fun at later levels). The 10 Mythic Paths add an additional layer of power, flavour, and story; not only do they give you new abilities to help allies and harm enemies, they add story interactions with unique endings as well as a variety of mechanics. For example, you can take Angelic powers to heal your allies and smite the evil, Demonic powers to feed your inner hatred for mortals, become a Trickster that pranks people, or an Azata (think 'fae') that extols freedom for all. There are also lots of companions with interesting backstories that you can engage with (or ignore as you see fit) - they're not as fleshed-out as Baldur's Gate 3 (few things are), but they are fun, interesting, infuriating, great, evil, etc.

On the flip side, the game is mechanically complex and this can make things frustrating, especially early when you're trying to learn how the system works. Where Baldur's Gate 3 took the D&D 5e system and faithfully rebuilt it in videogame form (with some features trimmed to keep things stable), Wrath of the Righteous goes a step further to map the Pathfinder 1e (PF1e) systems almost one-to-one in WotR. PF1e is VERY complex, full of little mechanics behind the scenes that affect how combat works which can make it very difficult to understand why your attacks aren't hitting consistently, or doing less damage than you thought. This also swings in the other direction, where sometimes you'll hit harder / more often; 'Touch AC', for example, is the AC (Armor Class) of a creature when attacked with a Touch Attack. It tends to be much lower for larger creatures, so when a creature has a typical AC of 20, its Touch AC might be 10, making it much easier to hit (and crit) with Touch attacks.

The mechanically dense combat makes things even harder in later chapters, where enemies will have MASSIVE saves and AC; these are easy problems to solve if you know how to make good use of spells and abilities to reduce/bypass these issues, but it still makes combat drag a bit unless you've managed to build something truly overpowered (which is not only possible, but quite easy if you know what you're doing, or copy someone else's broken build).

With the above said, I really do think Wrath of the Righteous is a spectacular game, and if you can play long enough to reach the end of the first chapter, you'll probably be hooked! The story itself is very well-written, and there are lots of fun and interesting side quests, as well as a the Crusader army game once you reach chapter 2 (which you can choose to let the AI do for you, if you have no interest in managing it).

One last thing - in terms of DLC, you can just get Season Pass 2 - it has the best DLCs that add companions and classes to the main story in addition to some small but fun side areas. The rest aren't worth getting, in my opinion.

An incredibly ambitious game that mostly succeeds in what it sets out to do. The caveat is that it took many years of patches to reach this result. Its narrative conveys the desolation and horror of a demonic invasion. The depictions and descriptions of what that entails is impresses upon the player the stakes involved: nothing less than the fate of Golarion itself.

Unfortunately, there are many areas that lack polish, such as the Crusade mode, and many sections where Owlcat phoned in their encounter design. Stat-bloated enemies with abilities that they should not have are common. Obscure and seemingly unimportant decisions made earlier in the game can have profound consequences a hundred hours or more later, adding to hidden counters that the player cannot see, and locking them into results they could not have foreseen. Not necessarily a bad thing, provided it all makes sense. The amount of reactivity in this game is truly impressive, even if it sometimes doesn't land. Despite the game being billed as a power-fantasy, there are many times it insists that the player needs help when you really don't. I suppose that's the difficulty of having to account for the new CRPG players as well as the experienced. Not all mythic paths are made equally well, either. The quality differences between those that were added later compared to those that first shipped with the game are stark.

The core problem I have with this game is its encounter design. Owlcat can clearly program encounters capable of showcasing more complex tactics but usually opt for throwing masses of increasingly higher level enemies at the player, often with some kind of cheesy catch involved. They populate the map and wait for you to trip over them as discrete encounters that don't interact with each other in any way. You do see novel encounters, don't get me wrong, but there's a lot of filler. Some of the best moments are desperate fights against waves of demons teleporting or flying in to wreak havoc; demonic teleportation is one of their most deadly abilities but you rarely see it used well, which is a shame. 

Rather than stat-bloated encounters, I would have appreciated weaker enemies supporting stronger enemies by interfering with the player's attempts to counter them, and with fights being less frequent but involving at least one or two waves of reinforcements as the player's actions raise the alarm, and higher level demons call on their lackeys to delay you. Higher level demons teleporting around the battlefield would have also added to the chaos. Backtracking should also involve the risk that demons have teleported in to block your movement or even laid a trap in an area you think is safe. Especially in the later levels, high level demons would not hesitate to sacrifice their lesser peers as pawns in some tactical ploy. The player should feel harried and vulnerable, on edge against an attack that may come from any direction at any time. Alas, it's formulaic and ultimately predictable. You kill what's in front of you and what's behind you is always safe. Demons wait politely as you slaughter their fellows in the next room, and so on. There are a lot of different types of demons but you don't always see them working together effectively. Again, a shame. The measure of difficulty is generally Armor Class and Difficulty Class increases, and not much else.

I haven't spoken about the companions; all I'll say is that some are more entertaining than others. The puzzles in this game, involving a certain companion, were not to my taste. Neither was the decision to lock a large dungeon behind their personal quest, but honestly, it's just more puzzles, so I hardly feel like I missed anything. Except their personal quest is significant for the "secret" ending. Oh well.

Despite these complaints, the game is thoroughly entertaining, enough so to overcome its inevitable frustrations. A must-play for any CRPG fan. Please note, however, that most of the DLC is yet more filler content and much of it has poor reviews. The Last Sarkorian DLC is the only one I picked up and I don't regret it, though if you truly love the characters A Dance of Masks is apparently worth it.

This game has an incredible story, great lore, a super deep character customization system, and just plain fun.  One of my favorite games of all time.

Although I would recommend this game, I do so while advising that it is not for the faint of heart (You can make this game almost as difficult or as easy as you want to with custom settings).  I would give it an 8 out of 10.  If you want complete flexibility as far as character creation is concerned, this is a great choice.  If you like puzzles, this game has them... and too many of them in my opinion.   Don't expect to have your hand held throughout this game because there is nothing to really tell you where to go and what to do... there's a lot of trial and error involved.   Unfortunately, a person will spend a significant amount of time running around in this game as there is no fast travel on the main map.  The companions you can recruit are decent for the most part.  The voice acting, in most cases, is some of the worst but there are a few characters where the voice acting is top-notch.   Ulbrig, Regill and a couple of the demons come to mind.  Side quests are relatively meaningful and do contribute to the main story.  Graphics for this type of game are acceptable.   The music is good, but can definitely get old after awhile.  Fortunately, there is an option to turn it way down in the sound menu.  The enemies become very repetitious after a while, but the boss fights are typically unique and challenging.   Most of the loot is beneficial and it is easy to find some great powerful items to use... especially as one progresses.   Unfortunately, the game was designed in a way where speaking with random NPCs is somewhat important at times.   There is no way to place a personal map marker on any of the maps either... which is unfortunate.   (There are probably some mods out there though).  All in all, I thought this game was good, and I finally finished after almost 200 hours.  Granted, at least 20 or more of those hours were spent returning to areas I had missed, solving ridiculous puzzles, etc.  If a person wanted to manage the entire crusade and do the main story and the DLC, you could easily spend way more than 200 hours playing.  Speaking of the DLC... meh... if I had to do it over again, I would not have purchased it.   In summary, WoTR was a great followup to Kingmaker and I don't regret buying it.   There is  great replay value after putting it away for a year or two as well.   If you can snag this game on sale, go for it.  Especially if you are a fan of CRPGs.

It's a good game. It's got a classic old-school feel, but with a modern polish. If you've never played Pathfinder but have played/loved D&D 3.5, you'll feel right at home here. It's like if Baldur's Gate II and Neverwinter Nights 1 had a gaming baby that needed its own non-D&D identity.

Did you absolutely love D&D 3.5 (NWN1/2) but always wanted SO MUCH more of it? This game is here for you! There are more customizations, classes, feats, abilities, powers, and builds than you'll ever play through in your lifetime here. I'd call it something like D&D 3.9. Lots of ways to deal with situations. And! You can play it real time with pause, OR turn based. And you can toggle this option on and off at your whim with a button on the quick-bar! Brilliant!

Also, get the Toy Box and Camera mods for massive customization and accessibility if you're into that sort of thing.

If you're on the fence, buy it on sale--it's a steal at the 50%+ off price point (how I got it).

EDIT: There's an entire Birthright-style war campaign in the game, too! Birthright is/was a 2e Campaign that harkened back to the original concept of Dungeons and Dragons, which was a ruleset for a war game called Chainmail.

In comparison to Pathfinder: Kingmaker, this one feels a lot like Divinity: Original Sin 2 felt in comparison to the first game in its own series. They're basically "the same game" in the sense that the game mechanics, visuals, etc, are almost identical, but at the same time it's an improved experience that does a better job of telling its own story, has more interesting characters and side quests, either simplifies needlessly complex systems or further details the ones that could benefit from more complexity as well as adding some much needed QoL features, etc. 

Even the visual presentation is at first glance exactly the same as in Kingmaker, but once you start playing you notice that it's actually more detailed and an improvement. The story is also more epic, since the first one revolves around building a country and this one is about fighting off extra-planar demon hordes while wielding powers beyond what normal mortals usually can muster. 

I had a lot of fun with it, and I didn't encountered any of the glaring flaws the first game had, such as unwinnable random encounters or timed quests that cause an automatic and unavoidable game over if you don't happen to read every entry in your journal in detail and get too caught up on doing side quests or managing you country/army. 

The only downsides I found were some bugs that prevented me from finishing some side quests or main story missions and, except for the DLC about a party in your characters' honor where the next prompt to advance the story simply never appeared, all of them were fixed by simply reloading the most recent save file. I also dislike the fact that there's way too many loading screens that take way too much time and it gets annoying, but that's a staple of all the games I've played made by this studio.

I enjoyed the story, especially how it kind of does a similar thing as Planescape: Torment by trying to address the nature of good and evil and whether it's something that's part of a being's nature or it can be changed, and how most of your companions are written in a way that try to do something different or at least interesting with their archetype, such as having an asshole hedonistic aasimar or a demon who sincerely wants to repent and renounce evil. I also dug the free mini side quest featuring some characters from the game Children of Morta than find themselves being briefly transported to this world and meet your characters, since I played that one a few years ago.

Just like in Kingmaker, there's a lot of decisions you can make that change the direction the story will go, such as which characters to recruit, how to lead your armies, which companion to romance, what Mythic Path to follow, which enemy to kill or spare, and so on. It was a great experience and an improvement on the previous game in many ways, while telling a story that is different enough that the first game still holds up as its own thing instead of a lesser version of this one.

And that's before mentioning the incredible replayability brought by the mythic paths and the insane number of classes.

Huge game, it may not have BG3 level of production but it feels like it. First things first, this is videogame (alongside the Kingmaker) based of the TTRPG system of Pathfinder 1st Edition. As Kingmaker, both games are inspired (but not 1 to 1 recreations) of their respective campaigns of the same name.
The word is crunch, it is a crunchy RPG system, both on table and in videogame format, for the good and the bad. If you are the kind of people that enjoys to minmax character builds, party compositions, the value of this game is practically infinite for you. You are in for a very complex system that really rewards good planing and execution, and if your neuron activates something within you each time you level up and get to choose from of a very long list of diferent powers and builds, you are at home.
If you don't, you have ona of two chances:
First, you enjoy the story, characters, artistic design and all that is around the game while you play at an adecuate dificulty.
Second, bounce of as you get sleepy each time you have to re-read every feat, spell and option you unlock for every time one of your 6 party members level up.

You know you better than I do, so I'll leave the final veredict to you. But as is, this game is very very good value for the right kind of people.

I started this up off the back of Owlcat's excellent Rogue Trader, but with the distant bitter taste of my awful experience playing Kingmaker which I won't bore you with here. This game's depth and consistency of content is frankly staggering. A mass of character classes with six sub-types on average. A story that just gets bigger, and bigger, and bigger. An entire strategic army movement simulator "minigame" that links in to your roleplay and decisions made during the main quest. HUNDREDS of weapons and other items, most unique and interesting in their specific mechanics. This is one of the most indulgent experiences I've ever had playing a game, like eating my favourite dessert again and again until I barf.

It is not perfect. Depending on your tactical ability, you absolutely need to pay close attention to the difficulty options in WOTR, as this game has a lot of mechanics that I consider to be bullshit time-wasting grindy non-gameplay (no I'm not mucking around trying to find a resurrection scroll, thanks, everyone get up once the fight's over, chop chop). And unfortunately this is one of those games that STARTS really hard, with enemies that one-shot your tank, and then FINALLY gives you some decent tools and skills to actually deal with the challenges you face. And to be honest.......the game is just too freaking long. By the time I finished this I was exhausted and senseless. I barely read any of my epilogue because I just wanted to go to bed.

But who cares? 307 hours. What an experience. Well, guess I'd better start an evil playthrough.

TLDR
Pathfinder: Wrath of the Righteous is honestly a good game if you like stupidly indepth character building and being able to roleplay a character pick it up it'll scratch that itch regardless of it's problems. Long Review
This game took me a couple attempts to get into, the combat was the main problem. Turn Based Mode is ungodly slow to the point of being a genuine bore during some bigger battles and this is coming from someone who likes Turn Based RPGs. The Real time with Pause is awkward in a different way nearly 70 hours in it's incredibly hard to control, every half second you need to pause and reissue orders cause one of your characters obliterated the enemy you targeted and now everyone is defaulting to their AI auto commands which is usually just run at the nearest enemy or shoot arrows. Wish I could customise how my companions act in combat but ultimately it's fine just takes some getting used too 

The character building is amazing so many different classes to choose from on top of mythic paths plus weapon specializations just all around 10/10 character building this will keep my attention for a long time to come and I don't even have the DLC yet which some of them apparently add more archetypes.

I'm gonna talk about the other aspects of the game now and I'm gonna be honest kind of hate them as mechanics. The Crusade mode is an ungodly abomination and should've been cut from the game I'm a huge fan of grand strategy games playing games from Total War and Civilization to even dipping into HOI4 and Stellaris. The Crusade Mode which is basically a grand strategy gamemode is without a doubt the worst in the genre I've played for one it actively messes with your ability to just play the RPG aspects I literally got softlocked in Act 2 on the final fort to Dresen because my morale broke and I couldn't recruit new units and my army got obliterated by a spell caster general and I basically had to save load cheese until I got lucky and won. The morale is probably the biggest deal breaker, in the playthrough I got softlocked I managed to kill every enemy fort and every single enemy army except for one on the road to Dresen without losing a single unit and I went through Leper's Smile only stopping to help the Traveller and nothing else. According to this game's lore I'm cannonically the best leader of the crusades ever managing to do in 2 weeks what other commanders couldn't do in 70 years. Yet my morale broke because I let me army sit in camp for too long while I went and played the normal RPG section and it was only like a week of in game time not sure if the devs know this but real life armies wait around for months if not years, a week is not gonna matter at all. When your morale breaks you can't recruit your units skip their turns it's a pain in the ass.

Anyway my personal experience with the Crusade mode aside lets talk about it's balancing. It's also terrible Individual units amount to nothing they do pretty much no actual damage to enemy units compared to generals. Some basic enemy units are just infinitely stronger than the strongest infantry you can recruit (I absolutely despise ghouls). The balance around generals is also insane not sure how this made it in. You can recruit individual generals to each army which is cool however if you pick anything other than a Spell Caster as a general you are just shooting yourself in the foot. Spell Caster generals can one shot pretty much anything in the mode even massive 300 unit stacks, it'll either half health it or just outright obliterate it. The mode becomes stupid easy because of it however the enemy can also have spell caster generals which becomes a problem for the same reason, they one shot an entire unit each turn and your armies can only have a handful of units. Meaning if you're up against a spell caster general that has more units then you you're gonna lose just on the base line of he has more meat to sacrifice

As a slight upside you can just disable the mode and focus on the RPG however this apparently locks out content and I don't care how small the content is that is still stupid optional game modes become less optional the moment you lock shit behind it

There's also a city builder aspect which honestly I don't think I can give a fair criticism of it looks like it would be fun to manage however it's mainly tied to the Crusade Mode which just rots everything it touches it becomes a chore and has a lot of events you need to solve and they can lock stuff away permanently if you pick wrong.

I will preface this review by saying that I do NOT care if a game is too long. I absolutely do not care if your RPG takes 10 hours of 100.
I played Persona 5 for over 100 hours, and I played Royal for 120. I've played JRPGs since the 90s and have no problems whatsoever 100% them, and single play throughs taking  triple digit hours.
I'll sit down and play a full BG1 -> BG2 -> ToB campaign and love every second of it. 
Length of a game is not a problem for me - I will happily sit down and go through the expansive world, lore, character building, and the raw hours it takes to get through the campaign is a non-issue.

That being said, this game's campaign is too fucking long.

Miss
Miss
Miss
Miss
Hit (resisted)
Miss
Miss

That's pretty much the entire game, very poorly designed encounters. I liked it for a while, but the deeper you get into the game the worse it gets. You can install something like the toybox mod to try and bypass the worst parts of the game, but eventually you'll just be bypassing every other encounter. The encounters are designed around save scumming and having a very specific party with very specific skills that happen to be available, and that just isn't very well thought out or fun to play. Even encounters you win can take 20+ minutes of just you and the enemy missing each other nonstop. 

Attribute/level drain in particular is one of the worst thought out systems I've ever seen in a game. A common scenario is you have an encounter where you have maybe a 20% chance to hit anything, but then you are hit with something that drains points out of a given stat, or entire character levels, and so now you have a 5% chance to hit. You can use certain spells to reverse this (again, if you happen to have that character in the party, and they haven't used their spells already), but it'll just be reapplied in an AOE immediately after. And this isn't something reserved for a specific boss fight, half way through the game this is every other encounter.

The story is okay, not great, if you're not already familiar with Pathfinder lore then it feels like you're reading book three of a five part series and you didn't read the first two, just a constant barrage of wiki article info dumps. People complain about voice acting constricting what writers can do, and there is some truth to that, but this game made me realize that forcing some brevity on them isn't the worst thing in the world.

Navigating the map is a pain. You're moving the party as a game piece on a paper map, from one point of interest to the next, but you have to discover the 'trail' between two points as you go, and it's often unintuitive, you'll spend a lot of time just trying to find a connection between two points. While you're doing this, it's constant random encounters that start another long cycle of miss-miss-miss combat, or your party gets fatigued and needs to rest. Once you've conquered most of the map via the crusade system and you have teleports set up at each fort, it gets a little more bearable, but is never really good. I don't think anybody is looking forward to another 10+ half hour long random encounters and fifteen rest stops on their road trip to the next quest objective.

The game does offer a RTWP and turn-based system that you can swap between seamlessly, but even there it needs a lot of work, the NPCs in RTWP mode are braindead, basically never using abilities or spells. Turn based meanwhile just takes an eternity. 

All in all very disappointing. I'm shocked that they had an early access playtesting period and still shipped it like this.

Actual Review:
Although it's a pretty decent game, WotR is NOT an easy recommend.

I love both D&D and Pathfinder lore, and this game will do an amazing job at immersing you with its story and cast of characters. Roleplaying as a commander crusading against hordes of demons felt great as the game provides you with a number of Mythic Paths that give you unique powers (i.e you can lead the army as an Angel, a Dragon, or even an evil Lich). I can see a lot of replayability, but as I'm almost done with the game, I'm not sure if another playthrough is worth it.

That's because WotR is unfortunately BLOATED to the point of being grindy, tedious, and at times just plain boring. The game likes throwing trash mobs at you which makes most of the combat encounters repetitive (just like what MMOs do to drag things out). I also understand that Pathfinder is a complex system, but the designers could've picked the most impactful or fun mechanics from the tabletop ruleset to streamline your experience and make things more intuitive. I don't like how I COULDN'T enjoy this game without looking through other guides online. Also, Crusade Mode feels like a watered-down tactics game.

To wrap things up, WotR has its pros, but the cons are enough to hurt your experience. Some games just do it better imo. If you're looking for old-school D&D/RPG combat, Neverwinter Nights 1 does it way better. Dragon Age: Inquisition offers a similar experience with much more intensity and action (but focusing more on the personal rather than armies). And if you somehow enjoyed crusader mode army-management, the Heroes of Might and Magic series won't disappoint.

It's strange how much older games of this style gives the AI enough intelligence to do their own attacks when it suits the situations. In this, you can give an AI 1 ability to always use whenever possible, but that's sorta it. And they will consume them very fast.
I wouldn't mind having to control all characters if there were fewer but more dangerous fights - but when you have large amounts of it, it just gets tedious.

Clunky, ugly, generally quite awful-feeling. I don't even know why I can't tolerate this game, but it's just something about the whole package. Somehow even much older CRPGs like Baldur's Gate 1 and 2 feel much less "heavy" to play than this game. 

Here you have tiny maps that still feel awful to traverse, with your characters moving slowly and the camera being way too zoomed in. Just feels underwhelming as a whole from a basic mechanical standpoint. Feels like a low quality product.

I can’t recommend this game to anyone who isn’t already a diehard CRPG fan, and even then, it’s a rough ride. Wrath of the Righteous is an ambitious mess: a strange mix of brilliance and frustration, filled with bugs, balance issues, and baffling design choices.

I went into this mostly for one reason: to recruit Arueshalae as a companion and build my party around her. What I didn’t realize was that forty hours in, I still wouldn’t be able to recruit her, and that’s taking the fastest route possible. Realistically, it’s closer to sixty or even eighty hours before you reach that point. The pacing is glacial, and every chapter feels stretched for length rather than depth.

The core combat loop is less strategy and more rock-paper-scissors. You either happen to prepare the perfect spells and break the encounter wide open, or your entire party gets annihilated because you didn’t guess right.

In the first act alone, demons spam *Stinking Cloud* endlessly. Without a specific immunity spell, your party is paralyzed and doomed. Cast the counter, and the fight becomes trivial. This pattern repeats across the entire game: enemies are either absurdly immune or easily broken.

Resting, a basic mechanic in most CRPGs, is turned into a punishment. The corruption system forces you to constantly backtrack to safe zones just to recover, dragging out the experience. Every major encounter becomes a tedious loop of trial, error, and re-preparation.

Then there’s the tavern battle: a notorious low point that plays like a game of chess in hell. Dozens of NPCs wander aimlessly, wasting turn after turn, while you sit through the chaos waiting for the boss to appear. Strategy doesn’t matter, only patience does. The optimal play is literally to do nothing until the end so your party is fresh enough to win. Later fights continue this pattern with wave after wave of ineffective NPCs and bloated enemy groups.

If the gameplay is uneven, the story doesn’t save it. The writing is painfully generic: demons are evil because they’re demons, angels are good because they’re angels, and nuance barely exists. The companions join your crusade mostly out of convenience, not conviction.

To make matters worse, the game drowns you in walls of unvoiced text. Maybe 15% of the dialogue has voice acting which unacceptable for a game released in the 2020s. For a story that’s supposed to be epic and emotional, it rarely feels alive.

Visually, the game is serviceable. The environments are fine but uninspired, and the level design feels simplistic, sometimes almost mobile-game-tier. Once combat begins, the world itself might as well be static: no usable terrain, no line-of-sight tactics, no real environmental interaction.

There *are* glimpses of good design. The skill system is thoughtful, and the overland travel and army management could’ve been fascinating if they weren’t so underdeveloped.

But the class system is pure excess. Pathfinder drowns you in redundant archetypes: oracle, witch, mystic, magus, sorcerer, wizard, shaman, arcanist... the list goes on. Where D&D streamlines these into a few clear archetypes, Pathfinder feels bloated for the sake of complexity. The lines blur until nothing feels distinct.

Builds are broken beyond belief. Players routinely post characters with 50+ in key stats, making it clear the game was neither balanced nor properly tested. It feels like there was no real playtesting at all, just a sandbox of unchecked systems piled on top of each other.

Wrath of the Righteous could have been great. There are flashes of brilliance buried under its mountain of imbalance, tedium, and excess. But as it stands, it’s a game that demands masochistic patience rather than skill or curiosity. Unless you’re a hardcore CRPG purist with infinite time and tolerance, it’s hard to call this anything but a missed opportunity.

I think I gave this one a fair shake. Over Kingmaker, which had made a surprisingly late entry into my top 10 favorite games, I appreciated some of the technical improvements, new music, and so on; I really wanted to like it. Unlike many people who complained about the ridiculous numbers game, I was actually up for that now that I had gotten a slight taste of the Pathfinder 1e system and how to munchkin it a little,. I even bumped up my difficulty setting to Core.

Unfortunately, it lacks the degree of layered, networked storytelling that had me falling in love with the River Kingdoms and their peoples in Owlcat’s previous Pathfinder title, and so ultimately failed to hold my continued interest in a game of this length. That’s pretty difficult to elaborate on. How about this: I’ll take a couple stabs at it, and perhaps you can decide to give yourself the green light to play the game because you just plumb feel differently about these issues.

Attempt #1: It’s the difference between things happening and powers being gained because of chains of causality bouncing and tangenting off each other such that your character appears to have built something important, versus the same as a reward for beating stages in a video game. I understand that many players, perhaps a majority, are more attracted to WotR’s storytelling style (compared to KM’s) in the first place—like woo superpowers here we go, woohoo new teammate they get superpowers too as long as they’re technically in my party (even if I didn’t put them there)—but it puts me off because I neither feel like it’s been earned through narrative weight nor like I should be in some way grateful that it was predestined.

Attempt #2: CRPG companions are annoying weirdos as a rule, but this litter doesn’t enthuse me nor grow on me like the previous crop did. They’re a little flatter, which is not the worst thing necessarily, but I would prefer CRPG companions that are more than just a meme. For the most part, they also don’t seem to have credible motivations for standing by your side through thick and thin in spite of possibly huge disagreements; this is the baseline character depth for RPG party members, isn’t it?

Truth is, I still feel like I might revisit WotR one day and perhaps even change my mind, but I haven’t been back after two years despite thinking it was a better game on paper, and I didn’t even reach the part where most of the story’s detractors tap out. At least I got 126 hours out of it, you know? But it’s a sour taste for now.

Ugggghhhh I want to say buy this because it really is an amazing game. And upfront I will say my class and subclass seemed to play a large part in the issue, I assume other classes work better (my party members didn't seem quite as broken as I was), but I felt like I was banging my head against a wall the entire time I played this game, just waiting for things to finally start working the way they should.

I came into this with a background playing and DMing DnD 5e and (foolishly) assumed this would be an good basis for getting to grips with this game. It was not. The problem is that everything in this game is stupidly complicated, doesn't really work properly, or is broken. For example:

Broken:
I played a mounted fighter. The entire point of my class was to fight while on a mount. However if I were in combat and mounted, any time I wasn't immediately adjacent to the enemy, my mount would wander over to the enemy, stop beside them, pause for five seconds, then my turn would end. No attack for me. No attack for my mount. Just turn finished. Every. Single. Time. I literally could not attack while mounted unless I was on top of the enemy already. If only I could charge toward them! (see below)

"Touch" spell attacks on allies DO NOT WORK. These are the spells that I was predominantly (trying) to heal my party with. What happens is you select the spell. select your ally, then the caster walks towards the target, speaks some mumbo jumbo, burns a spell slot... and does not heal you.

Stupidly complicated:
In DnD you have an attack bonus for melee or ranged attacks. You use skills/spells/equipment to increase this. In this game you have an attack bonus which changes *every time you make an attack*. You can increase this through skills/equipment/spells except only some bonuses will stack but others won't and you have to try and piece together how to actually make this number go up without doubling/tripling/quadrupling on useless bonuses.
In DnD you have a saving throw for the spells you cast. This determines how difficult it is for an enemy to resist your spells. In this game you have a different saving throw for *every single spell in your spellbook*. Don't even get me started on spell resistance.
I could go on about this for hours, and I assume this is faithful to the Pathfinder ruleset, but if you don't know these rules beforehand the game is waaaaaaaaay too complicated and messy and confusing.

Doesn't really work:
My class mechanic revolved entirely around being able to charge into combat. The idea is I get on my mount, launch myself at an enemy, do a heap of damage upfront and then I either accept a decrease in damage output or run away and charge again. The problem is, actually charging an enemy almost never works. There is always an obstacle, often something completely arbitrary which looks like it should not be a problem, which prevented me from charging.

So I had a class which could rarely use the core mechanic (charging), and which didn't attack if I wasn't right next to the enemy, and which my healer would not heal even thought they cast a spell and burned through a spell slot.

I got about halfway through the game, it is absolutely massive. The story is amazing. The choices are endless, the companions are great. This is what kept me trying and trying to get into the groove for the ridiculous amount of time I spent playing this game. This should be the best RPG ever made. Sadly, it isn't.

If all you want is value for money and if you have a spare week to read and understand the rules behind the scenes, go for it. It really has some amazing stuff going on. If you think this is a pick up and play game that you can come to grips with pretty easily (*cough* BG3 *cough*) then turn around and walk away.

Either turn down the difficulty or pull up the wiki if you want this game to be playable. Wrath of the Righteous is certainly ambitious, and its main saving grace is that it works for the story. There is an impressive variety when it comes to how your character adventures through this world — colourful locations, weaving pathways, distinct endings — and these differences work well most of the time.
If only the complexity had any sense of intuitiveness when it came to general gameplay. 

Encounters are speedbumps: most of the combat is already decided by items and stacked buffs — lore-accurate Witcher level prep is the only way to track through the sludge. Build variety is extremely convoluted: you likely can get the game to work how you want, when you want, all it takes is a hundred hours of practice and half your sanity. My character unwillingly collected spell after spell, I was drowning in a paralytic abundance of choice: Netflix Browsing gamified. 

I burnt out multiple times through my hundred hour playthrough, the only remedy was forcing myself into catatonic drooling sessions as I loaded my way in and out of undercooked army management and awkward puzzle menus. The crusade/main-crew split admittedly provide a decent pace throughout — I rarely felt bottlenecked — but it’s so tedious to actually play. I wouldn’t be surprised if 10% of my playtime is loading, be it save-scumming (entirely necessary) or traversing across zones. Even with an SSD your immersion will take beating after beating, momentum frequently assailed by a purple bar and handy tooltips. 
I get it though. If you love the number crunch, the aura farming, the apotheosis before taking on a gang of spiders, well then you’ve found the one. This is it, build-a-bear (for adults) with an epic fantasy skin. It’s just not engaging for me, when it comes to CRPGs I’m looking for a great story.

And there are some genuinely interesting narrative threads, if you can stand the 10 hour wait in between the kernels. Characters do have layers (like ogres), and while companion quest content was unbalanced, I quite liked most of the gang.
There was rarely an obviously “wrong” choice presented. Good, lawful and evil seem to be equal in the game’s eyes — awesome. I was full on lawful neutral, my save-file ‘I AM THE LAW’ a warning to any rulebreakers or miscreants under my watchful Aeon eyes. I appreciated that the game takes you on a sojourn where the law is warped, and doesn’t purport what’s right or wrong. Good thing I'm infallible. 
The ending I got was rather neat as well. I just wish the game was way shorter so I can experience the others myself. What’s the point of all this variety in the narrative if barely a tenth of players finish the game in the first place?

This is a game designed to sap your time. It’s begging for polish; its presentation awkward, tactics shallow, builds bursting at the seams. I wish priorities were altered, only a little bit of tinkering and Wrath of the Righteous could be an absolute blast. 
There’s a possibility I return to the game, to do the Lich playthrough that’s been recommended to me, but you bet your ass I’ll be going in with wiki builds and a wooden stick between my teeth.

I backed this game on kickstarter. This is because Pathfinder Kingmaker is one of my favorite games of all time and this games announcement is one of only two games I have ever been hyped for.

Finding out there were time limits in Act 1 basically killed any sense of adventure or discovery for me. I enjoy RPG games because I can explore the game world, meet and interact with different characters. When they become locked behind a stupid arbitrary time limit, which is only discovered after about 10+ hours of gameplay, nahh... I just feel as though I've wasted my precious time because of a pathetic gameplay mechanic, especially when it isn't made entirely clear which are "priority" quest lines.

Miss
Miss
Miss
Miss
Hit (resisted)
Miss
Miss

That's pretty much the entire game, very poorly designed encounters. I liked it for a while, but the deeper you get into the game the worse it gets. You can install something like the toybox mod to try and bypass the worst parts of the game, but eventually you'll just be bypassing every other encounter. The encounters are designed around save scumming and having a very specific party with very specific skills that happen to be available, and that just isn't very well thought out or fun to play. Even encounters you win can take 20+ minutes of just you and the enemy missing each other nonstop. 

Attribute/level drain in particular is one of the worst thought out systems I've ever seen in a game. A common scenario is you have an encounter where you have maybe a 20% chance to hit anything, but then you are hit with something that drains points out of a given stat, or entire character levels, and so now you have a 5% chance to hit. You can use certain spells to reverse this (again, if you happen to have that character in the party, and they haven't used their spells already), but it'll just be reapplied in an AOE immediately after. And this isn't something reserved for a specific boss fight, half way through the game this is every other encounter.

The story is okay, not great, if you're not already familiar with Pathfinder lore then it feels like you're reading book three of a five part series and you didn't read the first two, just a constant barrage of wiki article info dumps. People complain about voice acting constricting what writers can do, and there is some truth to that, but this game made me realize that forcing some brevity on them isn't the worst thing in the world.

Navigating the map is a pain. You're moving the party as a game piece on a paper map, from one point of interest to the next, but you have to discover the 'trail' between two points as you go, and it's often unintuitive, you'll spend a lot of time just trying to find a connection between two points. While you're doing this, it's constant random encounters that start another long cycle of miss-miss-miss combat, or your party gets fatigued and needs to rest. Once you've conquered most of the map via the crusade system and you have teleports set up at each fort, it gets a little more bearable, but is never really good. I don't think anybody is looking forward to another 10+ half hour long random encounters and fifteen rest stops on their road trip to the next quest objective.

The game does offer a RTWP and turn-based system that you can swap between seamlessly, but even there it needs a lot of work, the NPCs in RTWP mode are braindead, basically never using abilities or spells. Turn based meanwhile just takes an eternity. 

All in all very disappointing. I'm shocked that they had an early access playtesting period and still shipped it like this.

Although it's a pretty decent game, WotR is NOT an easy recommend.

I love both D&D and Pathfinder lore, and this game will do an amazing job at immersing you with its story and cast of characters. Roleplaying as a commander crusading against hordes of demons felt great as the game provides you with a number of Mythic Paths that give you unique powers (i.e you can lead the army as an Angel, a Dragon, or even an evil Lich). I can see a lot of replayability, but as I'm almost done with the game, I'm not sure if another playthrough is worth it.

That's because WotR is unfortunately BLOATED to the point of being grindy, tedious, and at times just plain boring. The game likes throwing trash mobs at you which makes most of the combat encounters repetitive (just like what MMOs do to drag things out). I also understand that Pathfinder is a complex system, but the designers could've picked the most impactful or fun mechanics from the tabletop ruleset to streamline your experience and make things more intuitive. I don't like how I COULDN'T enjoy this game without looking through other guides online. Also, Crusade Mode feels like a watered-down tactics game.

To wrap things up, WotR has its pros, but the cons are enough to hurt your experience. Some games just do it better imo. If you're looking for old-school D&D/RPG combat, Neverwinter Nights 1 does it way better. Dragon Age: Inquisition offers a similar experience with much more intensity and action (but focusing more on the personal rather than armies). And if you somehow enjoyed crusader mode army-management, the Heroes of Might and Magic series won't disappoint.

I wouldn't mind having to control all characters if there were fewer but more dangerous fights - but when you have large amounts of it, it just gets tedious.

It becomes so complex that identifying with your character becomes increasingly difficult the further the creation process goes. Here already, the player is confronted with massive chunks of lore. A plethora of terms and names you won't ever hear from or read again but are seemingly important. My appreciation for this design is fairly low. In fact, I think it is bad design to hammer the player with irrelevant information to that ludicrous extent, when you just want to start playing. After character creation the game picks up quite nicely and the pacing feels right. You get hooked and the main objectives are clear. Once you escape the prologue into Act I, it goes completely downhill.

But you don't get to play if you don't become selective about what to read and what better to fly through.

Imo, the game does a bad job at telling you, what objectives should be pursued first and which are optional side activities. Points of no return are not communicated/indicated at all, which makes thorough exploration impossible with external guidance.

It is hard to recommend but I know there is a market for these games. If you don't mind reading through this review, you certainly won't mind my thumbs down. This game took me a couple attempts to get into, the combat was the main problem. The Real time with Pause is awkward in a different way nearly 70 hours in it's incredibly hard to control, every half second you need to pause and reissue orders cause one of your characters obliterated the enemy you targeted and now everyone is defaulting to their AI auto commands which is usually just run at the nearest enemy or shoot arrows. Wish I could customise how my companions act in combat but ultimately it's fine just takes some getting used too

The Crusade mode is an ungodly abomination and should've been cut from the game I'm a huge fan of grand strategy games playing games from Total War and Civilization to even dipping into HOI4 and Stellaris. Yet my morale broke because I let me army sit in camp for too long while I went and played the normal RPG section and it was only like a week of in game time not sure if the devs know this but real life armies wait around for months if not years, a week is not gonna matter at all. When your morale breaks you can't recruit your units skip their turns it's a pain in the ass.

Anyway my personal experience with the Crusade mode aside lets talk about it's balancing. I think I gave this one a fair shake. Over Kingmaker, which had made a surprisingly late entry into my top 10 favorite games, I appreciated some of the technical improvements, new music, and so on; I really wanted to like it. Unlike many people who complained about the ridiculous numbers game, I was actually up for that now that I had gotten a slight taste of the Pathfinder 1e system and how to munchkin it a little,. I even bumped up my difficulty setting to Core.

Unfortunately, it lacks the degree of layered, networked storytelling that had me falling in love with the River Kingdoms and their peoples in Owlcat’s previous Pathfinder title, and so ultimately failed to hold my continued interest in a game of this length. That’s pretty difficult to elaborate on. How about this: I’ll take a couple stabs at it, and perhaps you can decide to give yourself the green light to play the game because you just plumb feel differently about these issues.

Attempt #1: It’s the difference between things happening and powers being gained because of chains of causality bouncing and tangenting off each other such that your character appears to have built something important, versus the same as a reward for beating stages in a video game. I understand that many players, perhaps a majority, are more attracted to WotR’s storytelling style (compared to KM’s) in the first place—like woo superpowers here we go, woohoo new teammate they get superpowers too as long as they’re technically in my party (even if I didn’t put them there)—but it puts me off because I neither feel like it’s been earned through narrative weight nor like I should be in some way grateful that it was predestined.

Attempt #2: CRPG companions are annoying weirdos as a rule, but this litter doesn’t enthuse me nor grow on me like the previous crop did. They’re a little flatter, which is not the worst thing necessarily, but I would prefer CRPG companions that are more than just a meme. For the most part, they also don’t seem to have credible motivations for standing by your side through thick and thin in spite of possibly huge disagreements; this is the baseline character depth for RPG party members, isn’t it?

Truth is, I still feel like I might revisit WotR one day and perhaps even change my mind, but I haven’t been back after two years despite thinking it was a better game on paper, and I didn’t even reach the part where most of the story’s detractors tap out. At least I got 126 hours out of it, you know? But it’s a sour taste for now.

Ugggghhhh I want to say buy this because it really is an amazing game. And upfront I will say my class and subclass seemed to play a large part in the issue, I assume other classes work better (my party members didn't seem quite as broken as I was), but I felt like I was banging my head against a wall the entire time I played this game, just waiting for things to finally start working the way they should.

I came into this with a background playing and DMing DnD 5e and (foolishly) assumed this would be an good basis for getting to grips with this game. It was not. The problem is that everything in this game is stupidly complicated, doesn't really work properly, or is broken. For example:

Broken:
I played a mounted fighter. The entire point of my class was to fight while on a mount. However if I were in combat and mounted, any time I wasn't immediately adjacent to the enemy, my mount would wander over to the enemy, stop beside them, pause for five seconds, then my turn would end. No attack for me. No attack for my mount. Just turn finished. Every. Single. Time. I literally could not attack while mounted unless I was on top of the enemy already. If only I could charge toward them! (see below)

"Touch" spell attacks on allies DO NOT WORK. These are the spells that I was predominantly (trying) to heal my party with. What happens is you select the spell. select your ally, then the caster walks towards the target, speaks some mumbo jumbo, burns a spell slot... and does not heal you.

Stupidly complicated:
In DnD you have an attack bonus for melee or ranged attacks. You use skills/spells/equipment to increase this. In this game you have an attack bonus which changes *every time you make an attack*. You can increase this through skills/equipment/spells except only some bonuses will stack but others won't and you have to try and piece together how to actually make this number go up without doubling/tripling/quadrupling on useless bonuses.
In DnD you have a saving throw for the spells you cast. This determines how difficult it is for an enemy to resist your spells. In this game you have a different saving throw for *every single spell in your spellbook*. Don't even get me started on spell resistance.
I could go on about this for hours, and I assume this is faithful to the Pathfinder ruleset, but if you don't know these rules beforehand the game is waaaaaaaaay too complicated and messy and confusing.

Doesn't really work:
My class mechanic revolved entirely around being able to charge into combat. The idea is I get on my mount, launch myself at an enemy, do a heap of damage upfront and then I either accept a decrease in damage output or run away and charge again. The problem is, actually charging an enemy almost never works. There is always an obstacle, often something completely arbitrary which looks like it should not be a problem, which prevented me from charging.

So I had a class which could rarely use the core mechanic (charging), and which didn't attack if I wasn't right next to the enemy, and which my healer would not heal even thought they cast a spell and burned through a spell slot.

I got about halfway through the game, it is absolutely massive. The story is amazing. The choices are endless, the companions are great. This is what kept me trying and trying to get into the groove for the ridiculous amount of time I spent playing this game. This should be the best RPG ever made. Sadly, it isn't.

If all you want is value for money and if you have a spare week to read and understand the rules behind the scenes, go for it. It really has some amazing stuff going on. If you think this is a pick up and play game that you can come to grips with pretty easily (*cough* BG3 *cough*) then turn around and walk away.

Either turn down the difficulty or pull up the wiki if you want this game to be playable. Wrath of the Righteous is certainly ambitious, and its main saving grace is that it works for the story. There is an impressive variety when it comes to how your character adventures through this world — colourful locations, weaving pathways, distinct endings — and these differences work well most of the time.
If only the complexity had any sense of intuitiveness when it came to general gameplay. 

Encounters are speedbumps: most of the combat is already decided by items and stacked buffs — lore-accurate Witcher level prep is the only way to track through the sludge. Build variety is extremely convoluted: you likely can get the game to work how you want, when you want, all it takes is a hundred hours of practice and half your sanity. My character unwillingly collected spell after spell, I was drowning in a paralytic abundance of choice: Netflix Browsing gamified. 

I burnt out multiple times through my hundred hour playthrough, the only remedy was forcing myself into catatonic drooling sessions as I loaded my way in and out of undercooked army management and awkward puzzle menus. The crusade/main-crew split admittedly provide a decent pace throughout — I rarely felt bottlenecked — but it’s so tedious to actually play. I wouldn’t be surprised if 10% of my playtime is loading, be it save-scumming (entirely necessary) or traversing across zones. Even with an SSD your immersion will take beating after beating, momentum frequently assailed by a purple bar and handy tooltips. 
I get it though. If you love the number crunch, the aura farming, the apotheosis before taking on a gang of spiders, well then you’ve found the one. This is it, build-a-bear (for adults) with an epic fantasy skin. It’s just not engaging for me, when it comes to CRPGs I’m looking for a great story.

And there are some genuinely interesting narrative threads, if you can stand the 10 hour wait in between the kernels. Characters do have layers (like ogres), and while companion quest content was unbalanced, I quite liked most of the gang.
There was rarely an obviously “wrong” choice presented. Good, lawful and evil seem to be equal in the game’s eyes — awesome. I was full on lawful neutral, my save-file ‘I AM THE LAW’ a warning to any rulebreakers or miscreants under my watchful Aeon eyes. I appreciated that the game takes you on a sojourn where the law is warped, and doesn’t purport what’s right or wrong. Good thing I'm infallible. 
The ending I got was rather neat as well. I just wish the game was way shorter so I can experience the others myself. What’s the point of all this variety in the narrative if barely a tenth of players finish the game in the first place?

This is a game designed to sap your time. It’s begging for polish; its presentation awkward, tactics shallow, builds bursting at the seams. I wish priorities were altered, only a little bit of tinkering and Wrath of the Righteous could be an absolute blast. 
There’s a possibility I return to the game, to do the Lich playthrough that’s been recommended to me, but you bet your ass I’ll be going in with wiki builds and a wooden stick between my teeth.

I backed this game on kickstarter. This is because Pathfinder Kingmaker is one of my favorite games of all time and this games announcement is one of only two games I have ever been hyped for. 
The game being extremely buggy at launch, having worse UI and other baffling facts about this game I could get into honestly don;t matter to me much.
I quit early on for one reason, the writing. It feels so off. Like someone injected it with marvel writing, far too lighthearted even when the most extreme things are happening. It feels like every character is someones smug OC just mocking or making light of everything.

Finding out there were time limits in Act 1 basically killed any sense of adventure or discovery for me. I enjoy RPG games because I can explore the game world, meet and interact with different characters. When they become locked behind a stupid arbitrary time limit, which is only discovered after about 10+ hours of gameplay, nahh... I just feel as though I've wasted my precious time because of a pathetic gameplay mechanic, especially when it isn't made entirely clear which are "priority" quest lines.

Miss
Miss
Miss
Miss
Hit (resisted)
Miss
Miss

That's pretty much the entire game, very poorly designed encounters. I liked it for a while, but the deeper you get into the game the worse it gets. You can install something like the toybox mod to try and bypass the worst parts of the game, but eventually you'll just be bypassing every other encounter. The encounters are designed around save scumming and having a very specific party with very specific skills that happen to be available, and that just isn't very well thought out or fun to play. Even encounters you win can take 20+ minutes of just you and the enemy missing each other nonstop. 

Attribute/level drain in particular is one of the worst thought out systems I've ever seen in a game. A common scenario is you have an encounter where you have maybe a 20% chance to hit anything, but then you are hit with something that drains points out of a given stat, or entire character levels, and so now you have a 5% chance to hit. You can use certain spells to reverse this (again, if you happen to have that character in the party, and they haven't used their spells already), but it'll just be reapplied in an AOE immediately after. And this isn't something reserved for a specific boss fight, half way through the game this is every other encounter.

The story is okay, not great, if you're not already familiar with Pathfinder lore then it feels like you're reading book three of a five part series and you didn't read the first two, just a constant barrage of wiki article info dumps. People complain about voice acting constricting what writers can do, and there is some truth to that, but this game made me realize that forcing some brevity on them isn't the worst thing in the world.

Navigating the map is a pain. You're moving the party as a game piece on a paper map, from one point of interest to the next, but you have to discover the 'trail' between two points as you go, and it's often unintuitive, you'll spend a lot of time just trying to find a connection between two points. While you're doing this, it's constant random encounters that start another long cycle of miss-miss-miss combat, or your party gets fatigued and needs to rest. Once you've conquered most of the map via the crusade system and you have teleports set up at each fort, it gets a little more bearable, but is never really good. I don't think anybody is looking forward to another 10+ half hour long random encounters and fifteen rest stops on their road trip to the next quest objective.

The game does offer a RTWP and turn-based system that you can swap between seamlessly, but even there it needs a lot of work, the NPCs in RTWP mode are braindead, basically never using abilities or spells. Turn based meanwhile just takes an eternity. 

All in all very disappointing. I'm shocked that they had an early access playtesting period and still shipped it like this.

You can not play this game without a guide.  There is no kind of path to make sure you do things in the right order.  Unless you are a huge D&D nerd, you can't create a character or improve your companions in an effective way without a character creation guide.  

Its been really annoying to spend more time researching the game than playing it.  I've gotten to a point where it seems I should have done certain tasks already, but didn't and the game is forcing me to engage in a massive battle that I am not prepared for.  I lost the battle once, re-loaded, and got crushed again.  SO I went back to an earlier save, tried to do somethings I missed, only to have the game force me back to the battle again before I should.... 

A lot of other negatives to this game.  My teams hits at about 20%, wasted turn after wasted turn.  And the companions die a lot.  If I had played this game before Divinity or BAldur's Gate, I never would have played them... glad I played them in the order that I did.

There's a good concept here, but the execution of this game feels like a miss. There are a lot of "trash" fights, with many copy pasted enemies. The story can be interesting, but it is paced between many very long periods of traversing a very overly complicated world map. Navigating around the world and battlemaps is very boring and takes far too long. You must play this game either in story mode or with toybox, or else it feels like you are wasting huge amounts of time. The crusade mechanics are very bad, even if you turn them off they get in the way by timegating areas you can visit.

Enjoyed the gameplay up until the tavern defense mission at about 5 hours in. I've spent the last hour in this ridiculous fight. If I quit now I lose all progress so far, but based on other reviews the fight can go up to round 40 or 50 before the final bosses spawn, and I'm only on 15. It is just a seemingly endless wave after wave of fighting. Repeatedly spawning the same few enemies over and over and over again while you're at a low level with limited number of AOE attacks meaning it's just a boring slog of slinging low level hits back and forth at each other.

I really wanted to enjoy this game but this has ruined it for me. I don't have the attention span to sit through hours of endless stupid fighting like this. It's incredibly boring. Reddit has plenty of advice for how to extend your timer before this fight so you can go up levels to make it easier, but if you're like me with a smaller attention span and prefer fights to be done within 10 rounds, then this probably isn't the game for you either.

Additionally the character creation for someone unfamiliar with Pathfinder rules is a bit complicated. Too many options with limited explanations that don't fully explain how things work, or give literal essays worth of explanation that nobody has time or interest to read. It's not necessarily a bad game, but it's definitely not for people with small attention spans and more interest in exploring. Overall, would not recommend this game and wish I hadn't wasted my money.

That being said, this game's campaign is too fucking long.

Actual Review:
Although it's a pretty decent game, WotR is NOT an easy recommend.

I love both D&D and Pathfinder lore, and this game will do an amazing job at immersing you with its story and cast of characters. Roleplaying as a commander crusading against hordes of demons felt great as the game provides you with a number of Mythic Paths that give you unique powers (i.e you can lead the army as an Angel, a Dragon, or even an evil Lich). I can see a lot of replayability, but as I'm almost done with the game, I'm not sure if another playthrough is worth it.

That's because WotR is unfortunately BLOATED to the point of being grindy, tedious, and at times just plain boring. The game likes throwing trash mobs at you which makes most of the combat encounters repetitive (just like what MMOs do to drag things out). I also understand that Pathfinder is a complex system, but the designers could've picked the most impactful or fun mechanics from the tabletop ruleset to streamline your experience and make things more intuitive. I don't like how I COULDN'T enjoy this game without looking through other guides online. Also, Crusade Mode feels like a watered-down tactics game.

To wrap things up, WotR has its pros, but the cons are enough to hurt your experience. Some games just do it better imo. If you're looking for old-school D&D/RPG combat, Neverwinter Nights 1 does it way better. Dragon Age: Inquisition offers a similar experience with much more intensity and action (but focusing more on the personal rather than armies). And if you somehow enjoyed crusader mode army-management, the Heroes of Might and Magic series won't disappoint.

It's strange how much older games of this style gives the AI enough intelligence to do their own attacks when it suits the situations. In this, you can give an AI 1 ability to always use whenever possible, but that's sorta it. And they will consume them very fast.
I wouldn't mind having to control all characters if there were fewer but more dangerous fights - but when you have large amounts of it, it just gets tedious.

There are a few other issues but this is the most annoying one. Could be a fun game but, not for me.
